subject: RE: [junit] Re: JUnit Testing Code That Has System.exit(n);
msgSnippet: Teemu, While this looks like it should work, it turns out that Linux and OSX handle return codes differently than Windows. We have an open defect in JUnit
messageBody:
Teemu,

While this looks like it should work, it turns out that Linux and OSX handle return codes differently than Windows. We have an open defect in JUnit because of this. If anyone has a portable way to get a return code back from a forked Java process I'd like to hear about it.

Cheers,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute


_____

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of teemu kanstren
Sent: Monday, September 11, 2006 3:51 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: JUnit Testing Code That Has System.exit(n);



2006/9/10, Cédric Beust ♔ <cbeust@google. <mailto:cbeust%40google.com> com>:
>
> Back to the original problem, the only way I can think of is to sit down
> and
> think about what the return code really means: it sets a variable on the
> shell.
>
> So maybe you would fork a JVM that runs the code under test and then
> inspect
> the environment of the shell that was created and check the return value.
>
>
This is pretty much what I also suggested earlier.
something like this should work for it too (in your test code):

Process p = Runtime.exec("java mystuff")

int exitcode = p.waitFor();
assertmystuff(exitcode,...);
